The combination of a long bus journey, not much sleep, lasting sickness and a bumpy flight meant that weren't feeling the best once we got back on the ground, but it was worth it. Probably. It's one of the places I've wanted to see for ages, so it was good to do, but was a long time on a bus. Like a REALLY long time.

Speaking of buses, after the flight we were taken back into town and promptly got on the next bus to Lima, leaving in 25 minutes and lasting another eight hours. Joy.

The benefit of that bus was that we didn't have to stay in Nazca or get our second overnight bus in two days. Additionally, we got a decent dinner - pizza which hadn't been reheated in a bus microwave.

node.caption: We were pretty excited, and slightly delirious
I think this one was called the condor

post.content:
What's the best thing to do after spending 21 hours on bus? Another bus journey of course! I can assure you I wasn't this chipper this morning getting onto our eight hour bus from Lima to Huaraz. We were both thoroughly bored of our audibooks, the semi-functional screens playing films, games, and bus travel in general. The scenery was occasionally of some help - towards the end we had some stunning views of the white peaks in the Cordillera Blanca, but for the most part we had either never-ending Lima or never-ending desert. Just a touch dull overall.

We arrived (late) and checked into our hotel, then headed out to another pretty good pizza place. Normally, dessert portions are smaller than main courses, but not there. The nutella pizza we ordered was probably the same size as my pizza, but folded in half and served with a massive ball of ice cream. This restaraunt was litteraly the saving grace of the day.

After long bus journeys we tend to sleep well, but not last night. Huaraz seems to be an incredibly loud place - dogs, car horns, and yet-to-be-explained explosions somewhere between fireworks and cannon fire. Just to ensure that the place never falls silent, some people up the road from us had taken it upon themselves to play a lot of music very loudly until at least 3.30am. Admittedly, it may have been some kind of local celebration, but I have no idea. I mainly just noticed that it set off at least one car alarm which seemed to just be incorporated into the din.

We lay in until about 9.30am (it was blessedly quiet), then got up for probably our last planning day of our trip. We booked a day toour for tomorrow and the four-day Santa Cruz trek starting the day after. Rosie booked the remainder of our accommodation and (hopefully) made sure that the sleeping bag she'll get for our trek will be warm enough. We had a pretty big lunch at an Indian/Mexican/South East Asian fusion place, so have decided to skip dinner - we'll see if that has any effect on our trek tomorrow ...

We'd booked a trek starting tomorrow, so what better way to prepare than another hike? We decided on one of the most popular day trips from Huaraz - the imaginatively-named laguna 69 (the 69th lake in Huascaran National Park, apparently).

This did mean that we needed to get up at 4.40am - not really a problem given how difficult it was to sleep there. The bus was supposed to arrive between 5 and 5.20, but was late enough that we were on the point of going back to bed.

We caught a bit of rubbish bus sleep for the next two hours, then ate our packed breakfast at a restaurant in a small village. We saw a couple of different lakes (numbers 67 and 68, I think) which were both a bright turquoise.

Our bus stopped at the corner of a switchback in the road and we all piled out to start walking. After far too long couped up in buses during the last few days we were ready for some exercise and quickly made it to almost the front of the group. The altitude probably helped as we were at around 4,000m and are definitely acclimatised by now, while lots of other people there probably haven't been at altitude for long.

The path went from flat to steep to flat to steep. We made it up to the laguna with plenty of time to spare, so there were less than ten other people when we arrived. The lake is spectacularly blue, set just under a glacier that covers multiple peaks. We could hear the sound of a waterfall on the other side of the lake, coming down from the glacier.

We had some of our snacks (sweet and salty almond granola bars are surprisingly good) while more and more people arrived. We slowly got colder, so after about an hour and a half (and loads of photos) we headed down. We had a little bit of a wait at the botom for the rest of our bus to arrive, but not for too long.

Back in Huaraz, we changed hotel so that we could actually get some sleep. The decent warm shower was a great bonus. We tried to return to the same restaurant as the night before as it was close, quick and tasty, but it closes on Sundays. We decided on another pizza place, but regretted it when we realised just how slow and inefficient their system was. It took them 50 minutes to make like 8 pizzas.

Back in the hotel (later than we would like), we packed for our four-day trek and finally got some sleep.

node.caption: The fist lagoon we went to
When your shirt matches the water

post.content:
Another early morning to get promptly picked up by a bus at 5.15am. We tried, not particularly successfully, to get a bit more sleep, then found ourselves at the same village and restaurant as yesterday for breakfast.

We started to get to know our group: two American guys who worked as programmers, two American women, a British couple in the last month of a 9-month trip, and a Polish guy in Peru for a month or two.

We had a long drive up a road with many, many switchbacks beside Peru's highest mountain, Huascaran. We reached the highest point of our trek (4,767m) while in the car, then slowly made our way down into a valley.

We started our walk from a small village, with bits of gradual up and down. It was a relatively easy four hours' walk, but slow. That was probably good, as some of the others hadn't been at altitude for that long and one guy had had some unpleasant altitude sickness symptoms. The scenery, however, was stunning as we are surrounded by jagged peaks, some of which are snow-capped.

At camp we had our obligatory tea and popcorn, then introduced the group to the version of President that we played on or previous trek. Unfortunately, one of the American guys went straight to his tent to sleep rather than eat dinner as he was sick.

There was a full moon that night, so torches weren't really needed. The glacier above us even seemed to glow as we got into our tent. It was truely stunning.

The tents themselves were decent - dome tents with entrances on two sides, plenty of space and a good porch. Most of all, they were warm and it was cold at 3,800m. The sleeping bags, too, were very warm - especially as there wasn't much room to move inside them and a drawstring to pull the neck closed tight. The naglene bottle full of hot water also helped keep me warm.

node.caption: The view from the top of pass
I can't get over how pretty it is
We were joined by some sheep for lunch

post.content:
Like on the Salkantay trek, we were woken up by a guide giving us coca tea. However, this was at 6am, practically a lie in. At least, it was for me - I don't think anyone else slept particularly well.

Today's walk wasn't that long, but did have almost 1,000m of ascent up to a pass at 4,650m, the highest point we'd walk to. It was a slow walk as the two American guys were both sick and had some altitude sickness symptoms. To make it worse for them, one of them sprained his ankle early on in the climb. To make it doublely worse for them, neither of them was a particularly strong walker and for at least one of them this was his first hike... ever.

We made our way up to the pass, stopping frequently so we could regroup. Our guides had provided snack bags, which were very welcome: some chocolate, some sweets and a bit of fruit all in a drawstring bag, refilled every morning - possibly the best part of the trek, definitely the best bit organised by the company.

Eventually, the group split apart, so we got to the pass at different times. We took some photos and had lunch (stuffed peppers carried by the guides), but soon left as it began to snow/rain.

The campsite was only a couple of hours down the path, meaning we slept at 4,200m, even colder than the night before. I was so cold! We played President again, then a few hands of beanie with a subset of the group - neither of the American guys appeared at dinner and the American women retired early as they were starting earlier the next day to finish the trek in three days.

Up again at six, our group split into three - the American women had left with one guide already, the American guys went with one of the porters (and a horse) straight to the next camp while the remaining five of us went with the lead guide up to a lake before going to the camp. We all really thought the lead guide should go with the two American guys, but he didn't seem to want to, nor did he seem particularly good at dealing with their problems ... It really wasn't very encouraging and I'm still not totally sure what the point of the guide was because the trail was totally obvious and he didn't seem to have any first aid training at all.

The lake itself was spectacular, similar to laguna 69 but with a glacier actually entering it. Unlike laguna 69, there were only ten or so other people there. Over the whole four days we probably saw fewer than 100 people overall. On the way down from the lake we had a great view of several snow-capped peaks, including one that is apparently the mountain depicted in the Paramount Pictures logo.

Most of the rest of the walk was along a flat valley bottom that was almost a desert in comparison to the mountainsides. Our guide said it used to be green and lush, but an avalanche had uprooted all the vegetation.

We got to the edge of a lake and our guide, Cesar, stopped us for lunch. Or rather, where lunch should have been. It was carried by the porter with the American guys, but they were no longer there. He told us something had probably gone wrong, so we had to walk to the camp. We all scoffed quite a lot of our snacks, loading up on sweets and chocolate to get us through two hours of walking.

Maybe half an hour later, on the other side of the lake, we met the porter who still had lunch. One of the guys had been riding the horse, so they'd gone faster and were already on the way to camp. We all had some lunch (a delicious causa) even though we'd had our fill of sweets, then headed to camp.

Once we finished for walking we played some more cards while we waited for dinner. Due to our overly-large lunch we weren't as reluctant to wait until 7.30pm as we had been the day before. The promise of hot wine after dinner was also welcome.

There were quite a few domestic animals about, so we went to sleep to the sounds of dogs barking, donkeys braying and the occasional moo. I still managed to sleep pretty well.

node.caption: The lake was really this blue
Its amazing how quickly we went from mountain to dessert

post.content:
Our last day of trekking was pretty short. We got up at 6.30am and walked downhill out of our valley for three and a half hours. The terrain was rocky and occasionally steep. Rosie had hurt her knee at the end of the walk yesterday, so was a bit slower than normal, while the American guys were obviously feeling better, so were faster. We followed a river down, with great views as the river got wider and stronger.

We got a minibus back to Huaraz (three hours rather than the five it took to get to the start of the trek). The first half of the trip was down steep switchbacks on a gravel road with a massive drop on one side.

Back in Huaraz, we had a huge lunch at the house of the owner of the company, Orlando. We were then dropped off at our various hotels and said goodbye to the others. The shower in our hotel was very, very welcome.

We had dinner with Michelle and Mike, the English couple from the trek, at the first Italian restaurant we'd been to in Huaraz. We were all pretty tired, so once we got back to the hotel went immediately to sleep, happy that we didn't have to get up until 9am.

Today wasn't particularly eventful - our last truly long distance bus of the trip. We got up for 9am, then caught the 11am bus to Lima. We watched Justice League and the latest Thor movie on our little seat screens, then were pretty bored for the remainder of the eight hour journey.

Once in Lima, we got a taxi and experienced some of the worst traffic I have ever seen, not helped by getting stuck behind a traffic light that was red for five minutes. Worse, we didn't make it through the first time it turned green.

The best bit of the day was our food at the end. It was a Friday night, so the first four restaurants we saw were pretty packed, so we ended up at the pizza place we'd been to before. Afterwards we had dessert at the kroughnuts place beside it. Kroughnuts are a mix between croissants and doughnuts which Rosie has wanted to try for a long time. They were good, but not as good as a really good doughnut. It was international doughnut day and totally worth it.

Our room in our hotel was right beside the always-locked outer door to the premises, which meant that until around 3am people would knock loudly to be let in. Despite this, we managed some half-decent sleep.

We had breakfast in the hotel, then planned our short time in Lima (starting with laundry ... last time for the trip!). We found a great looking, but surprisingly empty restaurant that served brunch where I had a huge feijoada (a black bean stew) and Rosie had beef eggs Benedict.

One of the attractions near by was a park with a population of around 60 cats.

I'm not sure how they ended up there originally, but there's now a charity that looks after them. Rosie got some tea while I opted for picarones - traditional doughnuts made from sweet potatoes. We then went back to the hotel to phone home and get the diary caught up after our trek.

In the evening we visited as many alpaca-wool clothes shops as we could find, looking for a jumper with a very specific weave. Having almost given up hope, we somehow managed to find what we were looking for in the second last shop we knew of. We celebrated with a pisco sour each, our last in peru.

We returned to the same restaurant that we'd been to for brunh for dinner. They had a nine course tasting menu with a mix of traditional food that we'd had before and enjoyed (eg ceviche) among other dishes that we hadn't tasted. It was a great way to finish Peru (this time, at least).

Unfortunately the proximity of our room to the road meant that we didn't get much sleep this time. We were up at 6.45am anyway to catch a bus for the airport and ended up jumping onto a little collectivo, which was really cheap and dropped us off across the road from the airport. We checked in, grabbed some breakfast, made it through immigration, then got on our plane.

We'd been somewhat skeptical of our flight time - 10.32am seemed overly specific. However, the plane did actually leave the gate at exactly 10.32am. The flight was only a couple of hours, meaning that I missed the last 15 minutes of the film I chose (LBJ). For some reason it was also one of the bumpiest flights we've had, particularly from side to side.

In Quito, we got a taxi straight to the bus station, then immediately caught a bus to Mindo. We slept a bit on the bus and arrived in Mindo two hours later.

Mindo is lower than Quito, only around 1,500m, and surrounded by cloud forest. It's a small town and not that nice by itself, but with great scenery. We dropped off our bags at our hotel, then turned around and headed back towards the town.

I'd noticed that one of the main things in Mindo was a small-scale chocolate producers. We joined one other guy on a tour of their place, seeing cacao growing, fermenting and drying, along with the machinery to turn it into chocolate. We tasted several of their chocolates and chocolate products, including a delicious brownie and "cacao honey" made from the white flesh that surrounds the cacao beans in the pod. Rosie bought some of the honey and some cacao tea while I got some heavily-recommended fudge (more chocolate than fudge, really).

We had dinner at a little organic cafe with a set menu which turned out to be huge. To Rosie's delight, the young family next to us had a big, friendly dog which begged us both (unsuccessfully) for scraps. Afterwards, back at the hotel, the internet was actually good so we watched a few Sorted videos before sleep.

The breakfast at our hotel was huge, including bowls of tea and hot chocolate (you can probably guess who had tea and who had chocolate).

We took a taxi up the road to the "tarabita" - a metal box suspended on a wire across a canyon, powered by an old car engine. Along with four or five others, we took it across the 150m drop to get to the walking path on the other side. We followed the trail to five of the seven nearby waterfalls, avoiding getting too wet. None of them were massive, but still picturesque.

We took the tarabita back, then were offered a lift back down to town by a local. Back down the hill we had some arepas for lunch, then made it back to the hotel just before the rain really started. Stuck inside, we ended up watching several episodes of the crime series Castle (Nathan Fillion is great). Once the rain died down enough, we ventured out to find a highly rated (but empty) Italian restaurant for dinner, then watched a bit more Castle.

After another huge breakfast, we decided to go for a swim in the hotel pool. We immediately changed our minds after touching the water - nowhere near warm enough. Instead, we took our time packing up then checked out and headed over to the chocolate cafe to pick up a few more souvenirs. We found a cafe with some games to have lunch at and played cards until the bus to Quito arrived.

The bus ride was fairly uneventful as we'd downloaded a couple of episodes of Castle for the journey. Unfortunately I managed to lose my only jumper either on the bus or somewhere earlier today ...

After a taxi ride we checked into our hotel in Quito, then headed out to find dinner. We ended up in quite a fancy place with interesting, but somewhat disappointing, food. I had tongue, which wasn't as good as I remember it and Rosie had a balsamic vinegar cocktail. The cocktail wasn't great, primarily because it was made from an infused local sugar cane alcohol which we tasted later - both the base alcohol and the infusion were pretty unpleasant.

Unfortunately this morning Rosie wasn't feeling that great. We joined a walking tour which happened to be with the same company and even same guide as Rosie had had four years ago. We learnt about some of Ecuadors's struggle for independence and the recent collapse of its currency while also trying smoothies made from pretty tasty local fruit. We walked between different churches and saw some of the work going on to install a subway which will defintely be useful - Quito is very busy and very long, including some suburbs it's 50km x 8km soo is hard to get from one side of the city to the other.

We ended up leaving the tour early because Rosie still wasn't feeling that great. We had a snack and some tea at a cafe, then a small lunch. We also checked out a local chocolate shop which had won some international awards for having the best chocolate in the world (within some category). It did have very good hot chocolate - rich but slightly bitter from the dark chocolate.

Today was defintely food-focused as we also went out to quite a nice Spanish restarant. It was pretty small and only had a few other people and the guy serving us had developed the menu so knew a lot about the food. We had several really great dishes, particularly the salmorejo - a rich, cold tomato soup like gaspacho but with thinly cut ham on top of it.

This was our last day in South America. We packed up for the last time then left our luggage in the hotel. We had breakfast in a bakery (melted chocolate and hot chocolate for breakfast - that's a good day), then caught a bus to the middle of the world.

Ok, it ended up being two buses and by "middle of the world" I mean "Mitad del Mundo" - a point on the equator close to Quito that's a bit of a tourist attraction. It turns out there are two lines there marked as the equator - one calculated by an international group quite a long time ago and another a few hundred metres away calculated by GPS. There's a massive monument on the first line and a kind of outdoor museum at the second. Needless to say, we took plenty of photos at each.

We also went to a chocolate museum there, had a hot chocolate, had a local beer and had lunch. We'd been wanting to try llapingachos and managed to find them - a kind of fried potato cake. Before going to the museum, we tried to find the equator with the GPS on Rosie's phone and found out that it doesn't have a 0'0"0 - only 0'0"1N and 0'0"0S.

The GPS equatorial line museum was particularly fun. We had a guide who showed us several phenomena specific to the equator, although I'm not sure how many of them were completely true. The famous one is that water going down a plug spins anticlockwise in the northern hemisphere and clockwise in the southern. Our guide said that's only true quite far away but was able to demonstrate it using some trick. She also demonstrated that it was easier for her to push our arms down despite our resistance on the equator than beside it, but I'm not sure how that works. We also tried to walk along the line with our eyes closed, which is surprisingly difficult - it's noticeably harder to stay balanced. Finally, we each balanced an egg on the head of a nail as the equator is apparently the easiest place in the world to do so. Rosie was, sadly, much faster than me, but her job has included the need to be steady handed ...

After another super-cheap hour long bus journey ($0.40 each) we were back in the centre of Quito. We ended up going to a restaurant in the theatre - expensive, but it was our last night. We had better llapingachos, plenty of avocado and deep fried banana - a great way to round off Ecuador. Even better, dessert came with a shot of melted chocolate (twice in one day!). The restaurant was pretty nice, particularly the free taxi to our hotel. I also enjoyed the pan pipe covers of pop songs.

We got a taxi to the airport, then checked in (with the kind of expected faff around me having an ESTA). The flight was a little late, meaning we didn't actually leave at one minute to midnight, but our time in South America spilled into the next day.

We landed in Fort Lauderdale, Florida at about 5.30am with the thrilling prospect of a twelve hour layover. We found the bagel stall for breakfast (with a huge queue), then settled down in some seats. Rosie had downloaded quite a few episodes of Castle to tide us over. Throughout the day we moved several times to find working plugs and to stock up on food, but spent most of the time watching TV. Fairly uneventful, but it did pass the time.

The flight to San Diego was fine and we were picked up by Rosie's parents. While both of us will soon be traveling on, we consider this the end of our trip. At this point, Rosie's here for another two weeks before heading to Boston (and Edinburgh for graduation, among other places), while I'm only here for a week before spending a few days in Northern Ireland then returning to work in Edinburgh on Monday 25th of June.

It's been a fantastic trip, but I think we're both ready for a change. It's good to be back in a familiar place. That being said, we both still have repeated travel in the immediate future and neither of us have a flat yet, so we'll be living out of rucksacks/suitcases for a while yet.
